author: T Ramakrishnan
text:
India has invited Sri Lanka’s Minister for Fisheries, Mahinda Amaraweera, to discuss the problem being faced by the fishing community in both countries.

This has been welcomed by Sri Lanka, Renu Pall, Joint Secretary (Indian Ocean Region) in the Ministry of External Affairs of the Indian government, told The Hindu in response to a question whether the two countries were thinking of any new proposal to sort out the issue.

She said Foreign Ministers Sushma Swaraj and Mangala Samaraweera “talked about the intricacies involved” in the matter during the ninth session of the Joint Commission. The matter involved socio-economic issues and livelihood of fishermen, Ms. Pall added.

No date had been fixed for the visit of the Minister.

While Sri Lankan fishermen, particularly in the Northern Province, have been complaining about “illegal fishing activity carried out regularly” by fishermen of Tamil Nadu, the Tamil Nadu fishermen and political parties have been talking of “harassment” by the Sri Lankan authorities. As a result, the arrest of many Tamil Nadu fishermen and seizure of fishing boats have become regular features.

Noor Mohamed Alam, president of the Mannar District Fishermen’s Cooperative Society Union, said the Northern Province's fishing community had presented a memorandum to Leader of Opposition and the Tamil National Alliance leader, R. Sampanthan to raise the issue with Ms. Swaraj during his scheduled meeting on Saturday.

Sushma Swaraj and Mangala Samaraweera “talked about the intricacies involved”
title: India invites Sri Lankan Minister to discuss fishermen issue
